name: grobo
text: But Jesus needed ghostwriters to write his book for him, did Emeril?

text: Dude, Jesus is a ghost!

text: Not going by his biographies!

name: i_love_kate
text: I've always believed it to be an autobiography, and a self-serving one at that.

name: spinynorman
text: My friend (who is Christian) always refers to the idea of Christianity as either "salvation from a dead man" or "help from a dead guy." It's pretty damn funny to hear. Granted, one of the founding cruxes of the entire faith is that he's not dead, but reducing the whole thing to such a stark statement is worth exaggeration.

name: ananke
text: I believe it completely depends on which church as to whether Jesus actually or only metaphorically rose from the grave.

name: lexsenthur
text: Is his hand clear? If not, then he is alive, people.

name: hereward
text: Is that dexter ? Are you friends with the guy who is sinister?

name: selbencoirlo
text: What if it's not clear but you can see through it anyway?

name: johnnyrocker
text: What is your stance on translucence?

name: carbonation
text: Funeral directors across the land beg to differ.

name: jlynes
text: No, Emeril just needed a band and a huge audience of fawning sycophants to hang on his every showboating gesture in order to satisfy his horrible, aching need for acceptance.

name: sharktastic
text: Chubbied for truth.

name: tekende
text: At first I read this as "the affairs of cocks," then I realized it said "cooks." Then I looked down at my Snickers bar, looked back up, and read it again as "cocks."

name: saru
text: By "Snickers bar" you mean cock, don't you?

name: tekende
text: I was all set to be like "what? no" and then I realized that "Snickers bar" might be the greatest euphemism for penis EVER.

name: jesler729
text: So, yes.

name: tekende
text: Well, no.

name: spinynorman
text: I'm more confused than before!

name: tekende
text: Truth seldom falls cleanly from the bone we call euphemism, spinynorman.

name: wittyname
text: Goddammit, I read your first comment and was like "Damn I want a Snickers bar right now." Euphemisms aside, they are delicious.

name: stereo
text: Heh, bone.

name: spicyponyhead
text: Wait, I thought you called it a Snickers bar?

text: There exists a game (drinking) in which the players describe their sex lives in terms of a candy bar.  One would hope that theirs could be a "Marathon" and not a "Snickers".

text: well, as long as it "really satisfies" they should be right

name: soticoto
text: Not unless you're passing kidney stones at the time.

name: squi
text: This line firther deepends my belief that Mr. Bear should sound like James Earl Jones. No other voice could deliver that effectively.

name: jackparsons
text: George Sanders had a great dangerous voice. Stirling Holloway could have done Phillipe or CB. GS: the tiger in The Jungle Book, SH was Ka the snake. SH was also Winnie The Pooh.

name: blarghamagarky
text:
thank you for being as nerdy as me about voice actors

yes I know they both did regular acting

name: heccibiggs
text:
Ka and Winnie the Pooh are voiced by the same person?

Everything is ruined forever.

name: soticoto
text:
You're telling me that Ka and Winnie the Pooh are in fact voiced by someone who is not actually Jim Cummings?
You're right! Everything is ruined forever!


[ Subtext : Jim Cummings is the voice of every character you ever loved as a child and most of the ones you hated besides. ]

name: tekende
text: Kaa is spelled with two A's.

name: heccibiggs
text: Your mum was spelling with two As last night .

name: cpnglxynchos
text:
when we were playing Scrabble during dinner.

(the winning word? "Africa")

name: laserblade
text: That's...not a legal Scrabble word.

name: never_die
text: then you, my friend, have never been africa'd.

name: terribleman
text: In our house rule, any word you can explain the meaning of without laughing is a legal Scrabble word.

name: fineoakstructure
text: What about McAfrica ?

name: rowboat
text: There's just something really heartwarming about the use of "mum" in the British versions of "mom" jokes. I'm not kidding. I love that.

name: atticusonline
text: Mel Blanc was the voice of every character I loved as a child.

name: shutup_shutup
text: That is, unless they were voiced by Mel Blanc, Thurl Ravenscroft, or Billy West (or occasionally Chris Latta).

name: lizjones
text: But does Jesus have a limo that can pop a wheelie?

name: wittyname
text: Yes.

name: straw
text: Well, it's one of those Hummer limos, but I think it still counts.

name: gormster
text: Urgh. Jesus is not that crass.

name: numberkillinger
text: could Jesus create a Hummer so crass, that he himself would be too embarrased to drive it?

name: tekende
text: Yes, but then He would still drive it without shame.

name: twotonturkey
text: Did they even have port when Jesus was around? Was Portugal even invented yet?

name: andrew_
text:
No, but Jesus knew about Portugal. He also knew that Port would make an excellent dessert wine.

Fun Fact: When asked what he regretted most about the wedding reception, Jesus lamented his choice of pairing Muscadet wine with his fish when he should've gone with his gut and sprung for the Riesling.

The more you know!

name: straw
text:
Port's been around a little less longer than wine has been in what is now Portugal, which there's some relics of a wine industry there from the third or forth centuries BCE, well after the distillation process had been invented. However, the Portuguese wine industry of today started in the fifteenth century CE.

Portugal, along with the rest of the Iberian Peninsula, was referred to by the Romans as "Portus Cale," although Portugal recognizes the birth of its nation at the 12th century CE.

Depending on how specific you want to get, I bet you could say that port, Portugal, and Jesus all existed at the same time, although I would think it'd be difficult to get port in Bethsaida but then again he was Jesus!

name: i_love_kate
text: I'm sure importing liquor despite the weak infrastructure of the time was one of the more iconic of Jesus' miracles.

name: honesttom
text: Old skool Achewood!

name: ford
text:
Welcome to achewood, where on an average day you may find an elderly bear fucking around with an innocent young otter's mind. Also, there is a rich cat.


Sidenote, just found out that the spellchecker highlights the word "Achewood," looks like we need to get it into the OED.

name: cailetshadow
text: So... this has always been the source of my quiet humiliation!

name: dallovich
text: Oh, I love Philippe in that last panel! He doesn't understand what is going on, but most likely because of his past with Mr. Bear, he senses that he did something wrong.

name: beansdooma
text: so very deep

text: Cornelius is so hard as to tell the difficult truth to a kid.

text: Jesus turned bread INTO fishes? Oh Philippe, you teach me something new every day!

name: xiaomimi
text:
Thursday Blogs

Ray: I forgot everything I knew about computers!

name: rowboat
text: Ray could teach us a lot about the amount of time we spend here. If only we'd let him.

name: terribleman
text: "Chaos chop" is one of the achewood words I find myself using the most in day to day conversation.

name: pogo
text: The comments get real lean about this point.

name: lexsenthur
text:
"I'm more confused than before."

This is me every time I asked my father a math question.

The only difference between children and adults is adults stop asking questions like this.

name: daidai
text: When not on dry turf, despite his water-walking, Jesus falls short of Emeril.
